critique: This document is an executive order from Franklin D. Roosevelt approving an agreement between employers and employees in the Painting, Paperhanging and Decorating Division of the Construction Industry in Manhattan and the Bronx, but not Richmond. It is based on the National Industrial Recovery Act of 1933 and the Code of Fair Competition for the Construction Industry. The document reflects a strong interventionist approach to the economy, typical of the New Deal era. It also centralizes power in the federal government through the National Industrial Recovery Board. There is no clear indication of bias regarding immigration, national security, or social inclusion. The ideological tilt is moderately liberal due to the interventionist economic policies.
